abstracts.cdata!:
Overall the project is rated
            satisfactory, and the sustainability of the project is rated
            highly likely. Bank performance is rated satisfactory
            overall. The Borrower's  performance is rated
            satisfactory, due to its commitment to implement policies
            based on issues and constraints raised by the private
            sector. The key lessons pertain to the participatory
            process, private sector implementation, and donor
            collaboration: 1) The participatory approach for organizing
            the preparation and appraisal of the project holds promise
            for broader application. The project provides evidence that
            under certain conditions, participation can have valuable
            development benefits. These benefits take the form of
            improved project design, early and sustainable beneficiary
            commitment and involvement, and improved trust among the
            different parties. 2) Private sector projects, jointly
            supervision with the Government, appear to benefit the
            implementation process. Project activities were generally
            implemented on time, procedures were followed, and staff
            changes were implemented quickly and without major delays to
            the project. The issues raised, discussed or implemented
            were based on broad consultation and ownership by the
            private sector. 3) The project consulted and coordinated
            with all donors during project design, implementation, and
            in the review process. This contributed to a harmonization
            of donor funding and joint or continued funding of some activities.

18155806.theme: Export development and competitiveness,Other financial and private sector development,Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support,Regulation and competition policy
18155806.trustfund:
TF022566-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR
            COMPETITIVENESS PROJECT,TF020777-PRIVATE SECTOR COMPETITIVENESS PROJECT
18155806.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of the Private Sector
            Competitiveness Project is to make the Ugandan private
            sector more competitive so that it can expand sales on both
            domestic and international markets. To achieve this
            objective, the project will: 1) help improve the business
            and investment environment by decreasing policy constraints;
            2) strengthen institutions supporting the private sector; 3)
            enhance the dialogue between the private sector and the
            government; and 4) alleviate problems associated with
            inadequate know-how and the weak financial system. There are
            several beneficiaries from this project. First, the project
            will enhance the competitiveness of individual enterprises
            directly. Second, other stakeholders will benefit from
            serving as a means to this end. Finally, the government of
            Uganda will come closer to realizing its stated goal of
            building a modern, self-sustaining economy, based on free
            enterprise. The project consists of four mutually
            reinforcing components: 1) shaping the business environment:
            the private sector foundation component; 2) enhancing
            know-how through markets: the "business Uganda"
            development scheme component; 3) enhancing know-how through
            financial partners: the equity financing component; and 4)
            enhancing know-how through industrial partners: the
            investment promotion and facilitation component.
